winners.tagline: An ML-based web application to facilitate non-monetary donations to charities in urgent need.

description_sections.heading: Inspiration
description_sections.content: We live in a world of consumerism, where most people care more about acquiring products than their disposal. By the end of 2019, Americans are expected to have produced 35.4B of waste -- textile only. Only 28% of people donated unwanted items to charities. To make an impact on our environment, we need to think about disposing and repurposing used products as much as possible.

description_sections.heading: What it does
description_sections.content:
CharityMatch uses Machine Learning to identify item categories of item to donate from pictures that users will have uploaded. Given an item category, it outputs a list of charities that are most in need of this product category at that moment so that users can make an impactful donation. The list also displays the need urgency of the category for each charity. A map feature displays the location of each charity to help users plan their trip. Points are awarded to the user after making a donation, the amount of which depends on the urgency of the charity's need, with Tier 1 being the highest priority and amount of points, and Tier 3 being the lowest for both.

Built using Google's Auto-ML Vision API, Firebase, Google Maps API, Google OAuth 2.0.

description_sections.heading: What's next for CharityMatch
description_sections.content: In the future, CharityMatch could integrate the QR code scanning feature in order to track donations for all users to multiple charities. There is also the possibility of partnerships with rewards programs to strengthen the points system it currently has, so that users can benefit from offers and have rewards programs benefit from user acquisition and retention.

description_sections.heading: Built With
description_sections.content: firebase google-maps javascript machine-learning python react

description_sections.heading: Try it out
description_sections.content: github.com

winners.tagline: AR Currency Converter

description_sections.heading: Inspiration
description_sections.content: Many travelers struggle with the currency change when they are in a country of different currency. It is especially visible in Europe where eastern europeans, with their own currencies, travel to west, where the main currency is Euro. The see the bunch of numbers on the menu of the shop or restaurant, and they try to convert it into their own currency to have a better view point about how much they are spending, but they cannot calculate each and every calculation of conversion in their respective minds or cannot just search each one of them on the internet. We as a team come up with a solution to this.

description_sections.heading: What it does
description_sections.content: Rchange, is an AR based mobile application with which you just have to point your camera towards the restaurant’s menu and boom! The currency is converted into the one of your choice, not only one number, but all the prices which were on the camera are pointed to the currency of your choice.

description_sections.heading: How we built it
description_sections.content:
We built the AR based mobile application using Flutter because it enabled us to make a beautiful UI in a short time. Furthermore, Flutter enables us to make the app available on multiple platforms in the future. Designing was done in Figma, because of its amazing workflow and team libraries. We used the XE CD api to list and convert all currencies.

Backend was written using Python and Flask. To get the latest currency values to convert we used XECD Client which provides a simple Pip library .

description_sections.heading: Challenges we ran into
description_sections.content: The hardest part was making the AR work. Finding and parsing text in a still image is fairly easy thanks to the abundance of tools for this. Find and parsing text live in a viewfinder is a lot harder. We were able to find a way to do this using Firebase ML Vision offline OC..

description_sections.heading: What we learned
description_sections.content: It was the first time working with AR. We learned how to use AR in flutter and used a relatively low level custompainter API to draw the overlay.

description_sections.heading: What's next for Rchange
description_sections.content: We’d like to leverage the XE API’s historical data as well as prices analysed by Rchange in order to provide an API that allows users to: Predict price fluctuation in specific locations To get acquainted with local prices for products or services offered

description_sections.heading: Built With
description_sections.content: dart flask flutter python xe

description_sections.heading: Try it out
description_sections.content: drive.google.com

winners.tagline: Making Presentations Sublime

description_sections.heading: Inspiration
description_sections.content:
We wanted to make an AI-empowered workflow assistant to assist you with automated task to help you generate presentations, create voice memos, etc.

We feel that the Google Assistant is more akin to a Google Maid. It doesn't really fit within a professional environment. Our app serves as a logical extension of AI-connected voice assistants.

description_sections.heading: What it does
description_sections.content: Our application's primary value lies in its ability to connect you with your most important tasks. It gives you the ability to create data visualizations based on speech commands. Another application is the creation of lists/memos based on speech patterns. This app also gives you the abiity to shop for items on InstaCart

description_sections.heading: How we built it
description_sections.content: We built it primarily using UIPath and VoiceFlow. VoiceFlow's API was used to collect speech from users and parse it. Firebase was used to route data and prepare it for use by UIPath. UIPath was instrumental in automating tasks such as chart creation.

description_sections.heading: Challenges we ran into
description_sections.content: We ran into a lot of challenges using UIPath. It was particularly difficult to use Visual Basic combined with UIPath Studio. Connecting it to Firebase proved to be a challenge as well.

description_sections.heading: Accomplishments that we're proud of
description_sections.content: Successfully connected UIPath and VoiceFlow

description_sections.heading: What we learned
description_sections.content: We learned a lot of Visual Basic and the amazing utility of Firebase

description_sections.heading: What's next for Flow AI
description_sections.content: Expanding feature set to include richer options for presentation creation, ordering lists on third-party apps such as InstaCart, etc.

description_sections.heading: Built With
description_sections.content: firebase javascript uipath visual-basic voiceflow

winners.tagline: QueueNA makes it easier for students to learn more effectively by removing communication barriers between students and their professors.

description_sections.heading: Inspiration
description_sections.content: Our inspiration for creating QueueNA (pronounced "Q-n-A") came from our own experiences as students at university. Compared to high school classrooms, lecture halls are far larger, creating the first of the problems that we aim to solve: Students who do not want to ask questions simply because it would involve yelling across a large lecture hall, and even if they were able to catch up with the professor after the lecture, the information would not be as useful compared to if it was presented while discussion was still on the topic of the question. The second problem we aim to solve is to encourage students that are too nervous to ask a question simply because they think it is a silly question. By presenting the questions in a semi-anonymous fashion, these students will be able to ask questions while avoiding the shyness that some students feel when asking a question in front of a large class. Real-time answers make learning more efficient and help students succeed without having to worry about how loud they can shout or how silly their question may or may not be.

description_sections.heading: What it does
description_sections.content: The main purpose of QueueNA is to forward any questions that students in a lecture think of during the course of the lecture to the professor, where they can answer the questions sooner rather than later. This is done through a system that gives students an input field to ask a question. As soon as a student sends a question, it gets put into a list of questions for the professor to answer. The professors see the student’s questions on an external display with our web app. They then have the choice to answer it on their own timing (in which case, the current focus question will be displayed to everyone) or dismiss it, in order to tell the student to come see the professor later if the question is too complicated.

description_sections.heading: How we built it
description_sections.content: QueueNA’s frontend is built using a combination of React and Grommet. For hosting, database and authentication services, we chose to use Firebase because of the simplicity of adding the required functions into our web app with minimal time wasted.

description_sections.heading: Challenges we ran into
description_sections.content: One of the largest challenges that we faced during our development process was getting React and Firebase to work together. Firebase hosting is generally meant for simpler types of websites, which we learned quite quickly when we had to configure Firebase’s settings to work with a separate build folder instead of a project folder, among many other configuration issues. Another challenge that we faced was designing the UI - Grommet, while it had the potential to make a very good looking UI, was not always consistent between devices - the usage of ‘small, medium and large’ settings instead of size settings that used units such as em or percent meant that some UI elements looked off on other devices.

description_sections.heading: Accomplishments that we're proud of
description_sections.content: We are very proud of our work here at Hack the North this year. Through well-organized teamwork, we were able to develop an aesthetically pleasing web application in 36 hours while learning much about how to do it along the way. On top of that, for 3 out of the 4 members on our team, this was their first hackathon, making the challenge even more interesting yet fulfilling.

description_sections.heading: What we learned
description_sections.content: Throughout the course of Hack the North, we gained many new skills. For all of us, this was our first major project using Firebase, so experimenting with how it worked and how to implement it was a big part of our learning here. Some of us also learned the basics of WebSockets and the potential uses for it, namely the ability to update screens in real time from external sources. Finally, for some of us, this was our first time working with a front-end framework such as React, which proved to be an entirely different and yet very interesting way to build a webpage.

description_sections.heading: What's next for QueueNA
description_sections.content: Through brainstorming within our team as well as many conversations with both students and professors to see what our customer base desires, we have come up with several potential future additions to QueueNA. Firstly, a voting system. Without a system like this, the potential for duplicate questions is greatly increased, so by using a system where students can upvote other students questions that they are also wondering about, the professor can see which questions have the most interest. Secondly, we would like to add a classwide polling system to allow professors to poll the entire class to see how well the class understands a concept. Thirdly, the ability to determine whether or not a user is a student or a professor is currently being investigated. The easiest way would be to get a manifest of emails from the institutions that use our system, but we are also considering alternate methods. Finally, support for the LaTeX formatting language is being considered, as while there would be a slight learning curve, it would allow for far easier entry of mathematical expressions that are also easier to read.

description_sections.heading: Built With
description_sections.content: firebase grommet javascript react xe

description_sections.heading: Try it out
description_sections.content: queuena2019.web.app github.com

winners.tagline: Bringing user targeted advertisements via offline mechanism - Our technology benefits both advertisers and the viewers. It displays what the viewers want to see, and to whom advertisers want to reach.

description_sections.heading: Inspiration
description_sections.content: Offline advertisements are random and passive in nature, thus both the viewers and advertisers are at a loss. No one wishes to view advertisements that are not meant for them. Moreover, we spend most of out time walking on streets, driving on roads, roaming around in malls, visiting cafes and restaurants - Digital Boards showcasing advertisements are present almost everywhere. Thus, there is an immense need of intelligent advertising on offline mechanisms.

description_sections.heading: What it does
description_sections.content: It collects demographics of the viewing population via an image sensor, then it uses a matching algorithm to match the advertisements to display boards maximising user targeting and user suitability. The demographics taken into consideration at the moment are - gender, age group and eye moment to ensure long eye contact. The advertisements form a queue infront of each display board and are then displayed on the basis on realtime estimates via geometry and cost minimisation.

description_sections.heading: How we built it
description_sections.content:
PART - 1 : (Board to Advertisements) Matching and Queuing Technology

Camera on Offline Advertising Spots generates the demographics of the viewing audience using Azure Cognitive Services Face API JSON Data obtained is processed, centroid of viewing population for each billboard is estimated. These Centroids are maintained in Firebase Realtime Database. Advertisements and Billboard Centroids are plotted on 4 Dimensional Graph and each advertisement searches for the nearest billboard and enters its queue.

PART - 2 : Advertisers' Portal

Login is done via Facebook Login API Advertisers can check the following details : Viewership Display Time of their Advertisements Amount Spent Relevant Viewership Advertisers can make Payments for future display of advertisements via the payment page. Payment Page uses TD Da Vinci API for Transfer of Funds

description_sections.heading: Challenges we ran into
description_sections.content: The first challenge was to decide the factors that are prevalent for user targeting advertising. The demographic factors had to be streamlined to three for present working. Moreover, these factors were then processed via Microsoft Azure Cognitive Services Face API Handling Realtime databases is a tiring task, but Firebase Realtime Database simplified the process. Payment and User Login are considered to be very time consuming development tasks, usage of Facebook Login API and TD Payment API came to our rescue with these challenges.

description_sections.heading: Accomplishments that we're proud of
description_sections.content: We are proud to share that TARP is capable of displaying user targeted advertisements to the most accurate viewing strata of population in realtime. Moreover, it ensures that advertisers pay a fair price as costing is based on display time of advertisements ( of highest priority level), Percentage of Interested Relevant Audience along with multipliers based on average footfall.

description_sections.heading: What we learned
description_sections.content: We learnt how to approach critical problem statements in a structured manner and consider all the edge cases. We solved challenges that may arise in real time scenarios. We worked with the aim to make our solution on offline user-targeted advertising scalable and efficient. We adopted a business model that can bring stability to the dynamic pricing of offline advertising industry.

description_sections.heading: What's next for TARP - Target. Advertise. Revolutionalise. Promote.
description_sections.content: Next TARP would be processing high quality realtime videos and optimise the time efficiency. Moreover, the factors that segregate viewership preferences can be enhanced by including financial status of the viewers, expression towards the advertisement etc.

winners.tagline: Learning and Communication tool for disabled people

description_sections.heading: Inspiration
description_sections.content: We wanted to make sure that everyone has the opportunity to learn! We wanted to help a handicapped person have the opportunity to learn, just like every other regular student.

description_sections.heading: What it does
description_sections.content: We created a communication app that will obtain speech, and convert it into sign language for the user. It also outputs it in many languages, based on the languages the user can read.

description_sections.heading: How I built it
description_sections.content: We launched a flutter app, and knowing little about the upcoming language, we began by watching tutorials and becoming familiar with the framework. We used dart for the ios and android apps, and we obtain speech and convert it to text using a web app created as well.

description_sections.heading: Challenges I ran into
description_sections.content: We began by trying to incorporate SPRING, and Java into our tech stack. We wanted to use the real time speech-text using gcp and working around it with java, however we found a much simpler solution using a simple and efficient web app.

description_sections.heading: Accomplishments that I'm proud of
description_sections.content: Connecting all of our experiences into making a big project that has many levels.

description_sections.heading: What I learned
description_sections.content: We learned that working as a team with many skills is the most key component to any project. Apart from the new languages, this journey was amazing!

description_sections.heading: What's next for speakNow
description_sections.content: We will next use words to convert sign language to text in real time (instead of letters)

description_sections.heading: Built With
description_sections.content: azure dart firebase flutter google-web-speech-api html5 javascript python survey-monkey-api

winners.tagline: PowerCards helps to train your memory and sharpen your mind. Powered by Microsoft Azure AI, this app makes it easy to create new fact cards by analyzing your text and images. Enjoy the fun!

description_sections.heading: Inspiration
description_sections.content: I wanted to build a web app where anyone can play with interesting facts of the world. I decided to develop a memory game that is suitable for all ages. For kids, it will help them increase concentration and improve memory. For adults, it will help them exercise their minds and reduce the risk of dementia at an older age. Traditionally, match-up games and flashcards are played as separate games. But I wanted to create a new type of game that combines the characteristics of these games in a fun way. The game design of this app is the result of this effort. To make it easy for users to create new cards for the game, Azure Vision and Text Analytics API's are used to analyze the text and images the user drags onto the screen. Azure Speech API is also used to speak in high fidelity the messages on the screen in order to enhance the user experience.

description_sections.heading: What it does
description_sections.content: Easily generates cards with meaningful words from sentences and images using Microsoft Azure AI. Auditorily reinforces user memory by speaking the content during gameplay. Trains memory of the user, whether a student, an adult learner or a casual player. Searches for cards by keywords

description_sections.heading: How I built it
description_sections.content: I integrated Microsoft Azure’s Cognitive Services APIs, like AI vision, text analytics and text-to-speech, into the application using REST. I found the API libraries for Node.js quite easy to use. I used Angular 8 to scaffold the UI based on Material Design. I used Loopback 4 to create the API backend using a model-to-code generator. For the database, I used MongoDB because of its support for full-text search and NoSQL.

description_sections.heading: Challenges I ran into
description_sections.content: One challenge was designing the best user experiences given the time available. I tried different layouts by putting different ideas on paper. In the end, I finalized on one layout for each page and worked towards it. Also, nested groups of drag-and-drop panels turned out to be difficult to implement in the Card Editor. In the end, I fixed the issue by googling for a solution.

description_sections.heading: Accomplishments that I'm proud of
description_sections.content: Integrated some great Microsoft Azure Cognitive Services into the application on first attempt Built a dynamic single-page application with a responsive UI and a flexible backend that is easily scalable in real-world applications.

description_sections.heading: What I learned
description_sections.content: How to use the Microsoft Azure Cognitive Services API’s To divide and conquer To use good libraries to solve otherwise difficult problems.

description_sections.heading: What's next for PowerCards
description_sections.content: User authentication so users can create and contribute; users can also report mistakes and comment. Points & Rewards system where users can earn points and medals.

description_sections.heading: Built With
description_sections.content: angular-material angular.js azure azure-cognitive-services loopback4 mongodb node.js typescript
